body.p: As you recall, students report using many kinds of strategies for studying course material. You have just completed your post-Student Cognition Toolbox course Study Behavior Inventory. This current inventory measured the kinds of strategies you reported planning to use when preparing for future exams. As you know by now, not all study strategies work as effectively as others to promote meaningful learning, and cognitive science informs us that certain kinds of study strategies are better than others in helping students to learn. Laboratory experiments and studies of students in academic courses, just like the ones you’re taking, have uncovered the kinds of strategies that are associated with better learning. These strategies promote deep processing of material.

p.em: If you do not see your personalized report here (as a bar chart), then return to the previous page to complete the Study Behavior Inventory AGAIN.

body.p: Your personalized report on how you responded to items on the Study Behavior Inventory reflects your planned use of particular study strategies. The bar graph illustrates your agreement with each statement on a scale from “1” (not true of you) to “6” (very true of you). The bars on the left (items 1-8 on the survey) are those study strategies that are known to be associated with deeper cognitive processing and better learning. The bars on the right (items 9-16 on the survey) are those that are known to be associated with shallower cognitive processing and do not promote the most effective learning, and can sometimes interfere with learning. For example, for prompt 9, you should first try working through challenging material on your own before asking others (e.g., a classmate, TA or course instructor) for help.

The bar graph provides a visual representation to help you understand how you have managed your studying until now. The goal is for you to elevate the bars on the left (those associated with deep cognitive processing) and to decrease the bars on the right (those associated with shallow cognitive processing).

p.em: Parts of the SBI adapted from Gurung, Weidert, and Jeske (2010).

body.p: Gurung, R.A.R., Weidert, J., Jeske, J. (2010). Journal of the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning, 10, 28-35.

section.title: Reflecting on the Study Behavior Inventory:

body.p: Now that you have completed the Study Strategy Modules, you have the tools you need to help you engage in study strategies that promote deep processing. There will be many opportunities to use your newly acquired study strategies and it is important that you take advantage of those opportunities to improve your academic performance.
